subs.text: @delong Implicit in that (possibly misconstrued) question is that the function of the American political order is to improve the economic lot of Americans, which neoliberalism failed to do.

subs.text: @delong But that misconstrues both the purpose of the American political order and the goals of a significant segment of the American electorate.

subs.text:
@KurtBusiek @lithub In 1955, Faulkner attended a literary conference in the University of Virginia. He was bored by the speeches, so he decided to amuse himself by writing an episode of "Car 54".
He rewrote it several times, and the final version was printed in Esquire magazine.
subs.rawText:
@KurtBusiek @lithub In 1955, Faulkner attended a literary conference in the University of Virginia. He was bored by the speeches, so he decided to amuse himself by writing an episode of "Car 54".
He rewrote it several times, and the final version was printed in Esquire magazine.

subs.text:
@KurtBusiek @lithub The story takes place when a pregnant nun (played by actress Barbara Werle) is kidnapped by a gang of thieves.
This episode was never produced, but Faulkner was delighted with it. He sent it to his agent, who showed it to clients.
subs.rawText:
@KurtBusiek @lithub The story takes place when a pregnant nun (played by actress Barbara Werle) is kidnapped by a gang of thieves.
This episode was never produced, but Faulkner was delighted with it. He sent it to his agent, who showed it to clients.

subs.text:
@KurtBusiek @lithub Apparently, it was too expensive to shoot, so never appeared on the air. Faulkner was disappointed.
After his death, the story was forgotten.
subs.rawText:
@KurtBusiek @lithub Apparently, it was too expensive to shoot, so never appeared on the air. Faulkner was disappointed.
After his death, the story was forgotten.

subs.text:
@KurtBusiek @lithub In 2000, it was discovered by the collector Scott Meredith.
In 2003, it was published for the first time, in the book "The Other Side of Car 54, Where Are You?"
